concepts.name: Utilitarianism
concepts.description: A moral theory that judges the rightness of actions based on their consequences, specifically their ability to produce the greatest happiness for the greatest number of people.
arguments: Actions should be judged by their outcomes, not intentions
The greatest good for the greatest number is the moral ideal
Happiness and pleasure are intrinsically valuable
Moral decisions can be calculated objectively
counterArguments: It can justify harmful actions if they benefit the majority
Difficult to measure and compare different types of happiness
May lead to tyranny of the majority

concepts.name: Free Will
concepts.description: The philosophical concept that humans have the ability to make choices that are genuinely their own, not entirely determined by prior causes.
arguments: We experience making genuine choices in our daily lives
Moral responsibility requires the ability to have acted differently
Quantum indeterminacy may provide room for free will
Agent causation allows for self-determined actions
counterArguments: Physical determinism suggests all events are causally determined
Neuroscience shows brain activity precedes conscious decisions
Our choices are shaped by genetics and environment
Random events don't constitute free will

concepts.name: Skepticism
concepts.description: The philosophical position that questions the possibility of certain knowledge, arguing that we should suspend judgment on claims that cannot be proven with certainty.
arguments: Our senses can deceive us, making empirical knowledge uncertain
We cannot step outside our own perspective to verify truth
Infinite regress problem: every justification requires further justification
Dream argument: we cannot distinguish waking from dreaming
counterArguments: Practical certainty is sufficient for knowledge
Skepticism is self-refuting if applied consistently
Common sense and successful predictions support our beliefs
Methodological doubt can lead to foundational truths
